title: Israel releases 30 Palestinian prisoners after Hamas frees 12 hostages in extended truce deal
summary: More Israeli hostages have been freed as the cease-fire held for a fifth day. The UN says that aid coming into Gaza is not enough to mitigate the destruction on the ground and that the population is at risk of famine.

title: Champions League: Mbappé penalty earns PSG draw with Newcastle
summary: Kylian Mbappé's penalty in the eighth minute of stoppage time salvaged a point for Paris Saint-Germain in a 1-1 draw with an injury-depleted but tenacious Newcastle team on Tuesday.

title: The French government's new anti-smoking plan
summary: A pack of cigarettes will cost €13 by 2027, with a first step of €12 in 2025, announced France's health ministry. Smoke-free areas will be extended to beaches, forests and public parks, as well as around schools.

title: Germany's budget crisis must prompt Berlin to abandon its hypocrisy
summary: On November 15, the Federal Constitutional Court invalidated a controversial budget maneuver designed to finance Germany's reforms. The decision weakened the coalition and revived the question of debt, at a time when the issue is being raised on a European level.

title: Turkey seeks to replace its obsolete fighter jets
summary: Unable to obtain F-16s from the USA, the Turkish government has turned to the Eurofighter. However, it is currently encountering opposition from Germany, a member of the consortium.

title: In Brazil, one of the oldest films shot in the Amazon miraculously rediscovered
summary: The Brazilian Cinematheque in Sao Paulo screened 'Amazonas, o Maior Rio do Mundo,' a  feature film made in 1918 by Silvino Santos, which disappeared in 1930 before being found in 2023.

title: France dismantles international yoga cult, guru and 40 others arrested
summary: French police on Tuesday took 41 people into custody, including the yoga cult's 'spiritual mentor,' Gregorian Bivolaru, on suspicions of kidnapping, rape and people trafficking.

title: Indian workers are rescued from tunnel after 17 days
summary: On Tuesday, Indian rescuers brought out the 41 men trapped since November 12 after a mountain tunnel collapsed.

title: Death toll from Kenya's El Niño floods jumps to 120
summary: Kenya's death toll from flash flooding has risen sharply. The country is facing the disaster just as it emerges from its worst drought in decades.

title: Pope cancels COP28 trip due to illness
summary: The Pope was scheduled to leave Rome on Friday but cancelled his trip due to flu.

title: Saudi capital Riyadh to host World Expo 2030
summary: Saudi Arabia will be hosting the World Expo in 2030, beating Busan and Rome for an event that should draw millions of visitors.

title: Top French court upholds Uber conviction
summary: Judges at France's top court on Tuesday said that Uber provided an illegal taxi service with its product Uber Pop.

title: France presents new biodiversity strategy, with no decisions on pesticides or agriculture
summary: The French government presented the third edition of its national biodiversity strategy, comprised of 40 measures and 200 actions. Not all environmental organizations were left convinced.

title: Finland says it will close entire border with Russia
summary: Finland plans to close the last open section of border with Russia over security concerns, after Russia reportedly helped migrants cross from Russia.

title: Israel-Hamas war: Fragile truce extended to allow further hostage and prisoner exchanges
summary: Israel and Hamas have agreed to a further two-day pause in the fighting. On Monday, 11 hostages, including three French-Israelis, were exchanged for Palestinian detainees.

title: Paris metro tickets will almost double in price for Olympics
summary: The steep price rise will run from July 20 until September 8.

title: Australia's offer of climate asylum to Tuvalu sparks controversy
summary: In the world's first climate migration agreement, Australia has offered to take in Tuvaluans threatened by rising sea levels. But in exchange, it will have a say in any security and defense partnerships that Tuvalu wants to sign.

title: The strike keeps rolling at the Centre Pompidou
summary: Staff at the Paris facility, concerned about the consequences of its closure for renovation, are up against the Ministry of Culture, which refuses to commit to the non-outsourcing of services and missions.

title: France to seek ban on three far-right extremist groups
summary: Interior Minister Gérald Darmanin said he 'will propose' to ban the groups, following the violent demonstrations over the weekend.

title: Intense battle for frontline 'fortress' Avdiivka playing out in Ukraine
summary: Over the last few weeks, Russian forces have concentrated their attacks on this industrial city in the Donbas region, sustaining heavy losses to do so. The scene is reminiscent of the capture of Bakhmut in the spring.

title: Rosalynn Carter honored by family, friends, first ladies and presidents, including husband Jimmy
summary: Former US president Jimmy Carter, 99, made a rare public appearance Tuesday to join his successors Joe Biden and Bill Clinton and all five living first ladies at the memorial service for his beloved wife. The humanitarian died on November 19 at the age of 96.

title: In a Hungary devoid of immigrants, the new arrival of foreign workers raises tensions
summary: In the east of the country, the huge construction site of a BMW factory has led to the arrival of workers from Asia, or 'guests,' in the terminology of Viktor Orbán's government. In this region, however, the population is fired up by the ruling party's anti-immigrant rhetoric.

title: European Commission proposes tougher legislation against human traffickers
summary: According to Frontex, over 90% of irregular migrants arriving in the European Union have been forced to pay traffickers at some point during their journey.

title: In an era of demographic decline in Russia, the right to abortion is under attack
summary: In the name of defending 'traditional values,' and at a time when the population is shrinking, many politicians are increasingly attacking the right to abortion and challenging women's liberation and right to work.

title: Dutch version of British Royal book scrapped amid race reports
summary: According to the British press, the Dutch version of 'Endgame' named the royal at the center of a racism row that widened the split between Harry, Meghan and the rest of the family.

title: Short-of-breath pope delegates reading as flu continues
summary: Pope Francis also canceled his upcoming trip to Dubai for the COP28 climate talks, on the advice of doctors concerned about his recent 'light flu symptoms,' the Vatican said.

title: Erdogan calls Netanyahu 'the butcher of Gaza'
summary: The Turkish president also accused the Israeli prime minister of inciting anti-Semitism across the world.

title: Macron's camp attempts to counter far right's narrative on French teen murder
summary: In the wake of the death of the 16-year-old boy in Crépol, the far right has spoken of violence from immigrant populations invading rural France.

title: The lack of weather information increases climate risks in Africa
summary: The continent has the least dense observation network on the planet, which compromises its ability to anticipate extreme weather phenomena.

title: Uber announces partnership with London's iconic black cabs
summary: Customers will be able to use the Uber app to book London black cabs from early 2024, the company said in a statement on Wednesday.

title: COP28: For the US, the climate battle will be won with oil companies, not at their expense
summary: Joe Biden will not be attending the 28th United Nations Climate Change Conference, which opens in Dubai on November 30, a sign of the country's changing stance in the run-up to the 2024 presidential election.

title: Forever chemicals found in the blood of residents of one French town
summary: Despite high levels of per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances (PFAS) detected in the water of the southeastern town of Rumilly back in 2017, the authorities have neither acted on this information nor alerted residents.

title: French justice minister cleared in conflicts of interest case
summary: Eric Dupond-Moretti was accused of having used his powers to settle scores with opponents from his career as a lawyer.

title: Israel-Hamas war: Hostages share initial accounts of their captivity
summary: Some of the liberated hostages recounted details of their daily lives at the hands of Hamas to relatives, the media and doctors. They were reassured by their general state of health.

title: For those left in one Ukrainian front-line town, 'no one dares to claim that we will survive'
summary: From 30,000 before the war, the number of inhabitants of Avdiivka, a front-line town  in the east of the country, fell to 1,600 after the Russian invasion in February 2022. Today, only a few hundred remain. Food and medical supplies are running out.

title: Israel says investigating Hamas report of baby hostage death in Gaza
summary: The armed wing of Hamas claims that a 10-month old baby, his brother and their mother have been killed in an Israeli bombing before the current truce.

title: 2030 Winter Olympics: French Alps designated as the sole candidate
summary: The International Olympic Committee supported France's bid over Sweden and Switzerland, while only Salt Lake City bid for the 2034 Winter Games.

title: Israel-Hamas:  How Le Monde navigates the image war
summary: This conflict, even more than others in the past, raises the question of where photos come from and how they are used. Whether for the newspaper's print or digital editions, Le Monde's editorial team is constantly faced with crucial choices.
